title: Tax Deductions and Credits
content: Welcome to our fourth lesson in Tax Essentials! I'm Taxxy, and today we'll explore tax deductions and credits in greater detail. Understanding these tax benefits can significantly reduce your tax liability and potentially increase your refund.

title: Common Tax Deductions
content: Beyond the standard deduction, several specific deductions can reduce your taxable income: Mortgage interest on loans up to $750,000; State and local taxes (SALT) up to $10,000; Medical expenses exceeding 7.5% of your adjusted gross income; Charitable contributions; Student loan interest up to $2,500; and Self-employment expenses. Remember that you'll need to itemize deductions (except for certain ones like student loan interest) to claim these benefits.

title: Above-the-Line Deductions
content: Some deductions, called 'adjustments to income' or 'above-the-line deductions,' can be claimed whether you itemize or take the standard deduction. These include contributions to traditional IRAs and HSAs, self-employed health insurance premiums, alimony payments for agreements before 2019, and the student loan interest deduction. These deductions directly reduce your adjusted gross income (AGI), which can help you qualify for other tax benefits.

title: Refundable vs. Nonrefundable Credits
content: Tax credits come in two forms: Refundable credits can reduce your tax liability below zero, resulting in a refund even if you owe no tax. Examples include the Earned Income Tax Credit and a portion of the Child Tax Credit. Nonrefundable credits can only reduce your tax liability to zero, with no refund of any excess. Examples include the Child and Dependent Care Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit.

title: Family-Related Tax Benefits
content: Several tax benefits are available for families: The Child Tax Credit (up to $2,000 per qualifying child under 17); Child and Dependent Care Credit (for childcare expenses while you work); Earned Income Tax Credit (for low to moderate income workers); and the Adoption Credit (for qualified adoption expenses). These benefits can significantly reduce the tax burden for families, especially those with lower or moderate incomes.

title: Education Tax Benefits
content: Education expenses can qualify for several tax benefits: The American Opportunity Credit (up to $2,500 per eligible student for the first four years of higher education); Lifetime Learning Credit (up to $2,000 per tax return for undergraduate, graduate, or professional courses); Tuition and Fees Deduction; and Student Loan Interest Deduction (up to $2,500). Income limits apply to most education tax benefits.

title: Real-World Application
content: Review your expenses from the past year to identify potential tax deductions and credits you might qualify for. Keep receipts and documentation for deductible expenses like charitable donations, medical costs, and education expenses. Consider consulting a tax professional to ensure you're not missing any tax benefits specific to your situation.

title: Lesson Complete!
content: Great job! You've completed the lesson on tax deductions and credits. You now understand the various ways to reduce your tax liability through deductions and credits, including those related to homeownership, education, family, and more. In the next lesson, we'll explore tax planning strategies to help you minimize your tax burden throughout the year.
